docs.snippet: A Federal district judge said today that freedom of religion was a legitimate defense in the case of a leading figure in a movement to afford sanctuary in the United States to refugees from Latin America.    Judge Hayden Head Jr. was speaking of J...
docs.lead_paragraph: A Federal district judge said today that freedom of religion was a legitimate defense in the case of a leading figure in a movement to afford sanctuary in the United States to refugees from Latin America. Judge Hayden Head Jr. was speaking of Jack Elder, director of Casa Oscar Romero, a refugee project of the Brownsville Roman Catholic Diocese, who is charged in Federal court with transporting three Salvadorans from Casa Romero to a bus station.

headline.main: LEADER IN MOVEMENT THAT SHELTERS ALIENS WINS A COURT ROUND

docs.snippet: Making a rare New York appearance, Saul Bellow will read from his works tonight at 8 in the Writer's Voice series at the West Side Y.M.C.A., 5 West 63d Street. Mr. Bellow, who won a Pulitzer Prize in 1975 for ''Humboldt's Gift'' and the Nobel Priz...
docs.lead_paragraph: Making a rare New York appearance, Saul Bellow will read from his works tonight at 8 in the Writer's Voice series at the West Side Y.M.C.A., 5 West 63d Street. Mr. Bellow, who won a Pulitzer Prize in 1975 for ''Humboldt's Gift'' and the Nobel Prize for Literature in 1976, will answer questions from the audience after the reading, then attend a reception. Tickets are $10 and will be available at the box office starting at 5 P.M. The information number is 787- 6557. BENITA VALENTE RECITAL In her only New York recital this season, at the Metropolitan Museum of Art tonight at 8, the soprano Benita Valente will be joined by eight cellists, including Timothy Eddy, in a performance of the Bachianas Brasileiras No. 5 by Villa-Lobos. She will perform with the harpsichordist Kenneth Cooper and Mr. Eddy in a seldom-performed Handel cantata, ''Lucrezia,'' and she will be accompanied by the pianist Cynthia Raim in songs by Schubert, Wolf and Rodrigo. Tickets: $15. The information number is 570-3949. WILDE AND WERFEL

headline.main: Friday BELLOW TO READ AT Y

docs.snippet: JIM JARMUSCH, who directed   ''Stranger Than Paradise,''   says he still thinks of it as ''an underground film that somehow crossed over.'' John Lurie, who stars in the film with Eszter Balint and Richard Edson, says he thought it might have some ...
docs.lead_paragraph: JIM JARMUSCH, who directed ''Stranger Than Paradise,'' says he still thinks of it as ''an underground film that somehow crossed over.'' John Lurie, who stars in the film with Eszter Balint and Richard Edson, says he thought it might have some cult success in Europe, but doubted that it would even find an American distributor. But ''Stranger Than Paradise'' has made its mark. It was named best film of 1984 by the National Society of Film Critics (a group Mr. Jarmusch says he didn't know existed) and won the Golden Leopard as best film at the Locarno Film Festival, not to mention a Camera d'Or for Mr. Jarmusch as the best new director at Cannes. It did better business at the Cinema Studio, Broadway and 66th Street, in its 14th week than in its first (it is now in its 16th). By next month, it will be playing on 43 screens in 33 cities.

docs.snippet: He was born in New York City 100 years ago this month, and he grew up in an apartment at 411 East 56th Street, an old row house. When he died 60 years later, President Harry S. Truman said: ''His melodies will live in our voices and warm our heart...
docs.lead_paragraph: He was born in New York City 100 years ago this month, and he grew up in an apartment at 411 East 56th Street, an old row house. When he died 60 years later, President Harry S. Truman said: ''His melodies will live in our voices and warm our hearts for many years to come, for they are the kind of simple, honest songs that belong to no time or fashion. The man who gave them to us earned a lasting place in his nation's memory.'' The man was Jerome David Kern, and his melodies included ''Smoke Gets in Your Eyes,'' ''The Last Time I Saw Paris,'' ''Ol' Man River,'' ''Long Ago and Far Away,'' ''A Fine Romance'' and many other of the best-known songs of this century.

docs.snippet: Despite the indictment of some of their leaders, church groups here and elsewhere said today that they would continue to give sanctuary to Central Americans they consider to be political refugees.    Supporters of the sanctuary movement, reacting ...
docs.lead_paragraph: Despite the indictment of some of their leaders, church groups here and elsewhere said today that they would continue to give sanctuary to Central Americans they consider to be political refugees. Supporters of the sanctuary movement, reacting to the indictment of 16 people on charges of conspiring to smuggle illegal aliens into the United States, declared they would put the Government ''on trial'' for its policies in Central America and in dealing with aliens. In addition to the 16 indictments, returned by a Federal grand jury in Phoenix last week and announced Monday in Washington, more than 60 other people, mostly Salvadorans and Guatemalans who entered the United States with help from the sanctuary movement, were arrested over the weekend. Seen The nationwide crackdown sharply aggravates the conflict between liberal church groups and the Federal Government, which says the aliens are fleeing poverty, not persecution, and do not qualify for political asylum.

headline.main: ACTIVISTS VOW TO CONTINUE AIDING PEOPLE FLEEING CENTRAL AMERICA

byline.original: By WAYNE KING, Special to the New York Times

docs.snippet: Two seven-foot Academy Award statuettes, the same that are seen on Hollywood's Oscar telecast each year, were among the famous figures at Carnegie Hall last night as the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences paid tribute to the smart, sophis...
docs.lead_paragraph: Two seven-foot Academy Award statuettes, the same that are seen on Hollywood's Oscar telecast each year, were among the famous figures at Carnegie Hall last night as the Academy of Motion Picture Arts and Sciences paid tribute to the smart, sophisticated screen style of Myrna Loy. Looking frail but glamorous in a spangled gown, the 79-year-old actress, whose career spans more than six decades, watched from a seat in the auditorium's first tier as she was lauded by colleagues including Lauren Bacall, Lillian Gish, Lena Horne and Joseph L. Mankiewicz. Film clips showcased her work from the early feature ''Show of Shows,'' in which she appears as a coquettish Oriental dancer, to the television program ''Love Sidney'' and with plenty of ''Thin Man'' excerpts in between. Later on, the audience of 2,800 watched the East Coast premiere of a restored version of ''The Animal Kingdom,'' a 1932 film featuring Miss Loy and recently rediscovered in the vaults at Warner Brothers.

docs.snippet: To the Editor:     The Isenberg murder and the Goetz subway shooting have thrown the spotlight on problems and frustrations in the criminal-justice system.   The Guggenheim Foundation has been toiling in this vineyard since 1972, and one study we ...
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: The Isenberg murder and the Goetz subway shooting have thrown the spotlight on problems and frustrations in the criminal-justice system. The Guggenheim Foundation has been toiling in this vineyard since 1972, and one study we are pursuing through the Kennedy School at Harvard University, with Prof. Mark Moore, has to do with the patrolman on the streets.

docs.snippet: When famous nonfashion names get involved in designing a collection of clothes for the mass market, the results are often not worth looking at. The good ideas are usually deemed too advanced and dropped, as if the benighted members of that market ...
docs.lead_paragraph: When famous nonfashion names get involved in designing a collection of clothes for the mass market, the results are often not worth looking at. The good ideas are usually deemed too advanced and dropped, as if the benighted members of that market have bad, or nonexistent, taste. Murjani's licensing agreement with Coca- Cola to produce Coca-Cola Clothes, as they are being called, may be an exception. The clothes are surprisingly good, which is why Tommy Hilfiger, who is 33 years old and who designed the collection, has such a big smile these days. Naturally, the collections for men and women each include the requisite five-button jeans (with a prominently displayed logo on back). But the collection is satisfyingly diverse. The clothes vary from crisp windbreakers and cotton chinos to brightly colored sweat clothes to jackets in traditional school stripes. Better still, there are trendy but well-designed items, including stirrup pants in sweat fabrics, beautifully cut polo shirts, cardigan sweaters with crests. And there are items that look like hot-weather hot sellers, including the Coca-Cola cotton sweaters with the logo emblazoned across the front in a spongy material. At a time when designer labels have become passe, that logo is strangely appealing, not, of course, that you'd want to wear it to dinner.

docs.snippet: The Council of Fashion Designers of America gave a party at the New York Public Library on Fifth Avenue Sunday night. The admission fee was steep ($500 a ticket), the dinner mostly home-style (chicken potpie) and the award winners eclectic (from t...
docs.lead_paragraph: The Council of Fashion Designers of America gave a party at the New York Public Library on Fifth Avenue Sunday night. The admission fee was steep ($500 a ticket), the dinner mostly home-style (chicken potpie) and the award winners eclectic (from the trendy Astor Place Hair Designers to James Galanos, the jewel in the crown of American ready-to-wear). The 290 people attending proclaimed it a big success, a lift for American fashion and a harbinger of further achievement by the designers' group, founded in 1963. Any party that has Bill Blass, Oscar de la Renta, Geoffrey Beene, Calvin Klein, Ralph Lauren, Mary McFadden, Pauline Trig ere, Herbert Kasper, Giorgio Sant'Angelo and Arnold Scaasi among its hosts is not likely to miss. They were some of the 98 members listed on the program who appeared as early as 7 P.M. for cocktails, sat down to dinner an hour later and could be home for the 11 P.M. news. They admired the stylish simplicity of the black-tie evening and the fast pace of the presentation, organized by Perry Ellis, the new president of the C.F.D.A.

docs.snippet: Cable TV     The week's cable film fare offers a colorful cluster of background scores for renewed appreciation. One treat is Franz Waxman's Oscar-winning music for ''Sunset Boulevard'' (Wednesday at 12:20 A.M. on WTBS.)...
